column1: I believe very thoroughly in courses of reading
column2: because I believe in having one book lead to another. But
column4: these courses for different persons will vary very much from each other. You all go out to a great picnic
column5: and meet together in some pleasant place in the woods
column6: and you put down the baskets there
column7: and leave the pail with the ice in the shadiest place you can find
column8: and cover it up with the blanket. Then you all set out in this great forest
column9: which we call Literature. But it is only a few of the party
column10: who choose to start hand in hand along a gravel-path there is
column11: which leads straight to the Burgesses' well
column12: and probably those few enjoy less and gain less from the day's excursion than any of the rest. The rest break up into different knots
column13: and go some here and some there
column14: as their occasion and their genius call them.
